intro: Silene wahlbergella subsp. montana, commonly known as the mountain catchfly, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central America. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its delicate pink to red flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in high-altitude environments. Its leaves are linear and hairy, while its stems are erect and often branched. It plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and habitat for small invertebrates.
